maml:description.maml:para: Gets an account that the DHCP Server service uses to register or deregister client records on a DNS server.

The Get-DhcpServerDnsCredential cmdlet gets a user account that the Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) Server service uses to register or deregister client records on a Domain Name System (DNS) server. The cmdlet gets the domain name and user name for the account.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the DNS name or IP address of the target computer that runs the DHCP Server service.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.

To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the user account that the DHCP server named DhcpServer03.Contoso.com uses to register or deregister client records on a DNS server.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes the credential that the DHCP Server service uses to register or deregister client records on a DNS server.

The Remove-DhcpServerDnsCredential cmdlet removes the credential that the Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) Server service uses to register or deregister client records on a Domain Name System (DNS) server. If you remove the credentials, the DHCP Server service uses the machine account of the system that runs the DHCP server to register or deregister client records with the DNS server.
Use the Set-DhcpServerDnsCredential cmdlet to add a credential.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the DNS name or IP address of the target computer that runs the DHCP Server service.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.

Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Remove a credential from a DHCP server

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command removes the DNS credential that the DHCP server uses to register or deregister client records on a DNS server. The command identifies the DHCP server by name.

maml:description.maml:para: Sets credentials that the DHCP Server service uses to register or deregister client records on a DNS server.

The Set-DhcpServerDnsCredential cmdlet sets credentials that the Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) Server service uses to register or deregister client records on a Domain Name System (DNS) server.
Specifies a PSCredential object based on a user name and password. To obtain a PSCredential object, use the Get-Credential cmdlet. For more information, type Get-Help Get-Credential.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Set a credential for a DHCP server
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Credential = Get-Credential PS C:\> Set-DhcpServerDnsCredential -Credential $Credential -ComputerName "DhcpServer03.Contoso.com"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example saves a credential on a DHCP server. The DHCP server uses the credential to register or deregister client records on a DNS server.

The first command uses the Get-Credential cmdlet to create a PSCredential object, and then stores it in the $Credential variable. The cmdlet prompts you for user name and password. For more information, type Get-Help Get-Credential.
The second command specifies the credential object stored in the $Credential variable for the DHCP server named DhcpServer03.Contoso.com.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Prompt the user for a credential for a DHCP server

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command sets the DNS credentials that the server that runs DHCP server uses for registering and deregistering client records with the DNS server. The cmdlet prompts you for user name and password.
